The Honor to receive of ſuch a Gueſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis true, Don Henrique, I am much ſurpriz'd
With what I find; I little did expect
Your Siſter Porcia ſhould have been—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Oh Heavens!Aſide. I'm loſt, he has diſcover'd all.
'Tis not, Antonio, in a Brothers power
To make a Siſter of a better Paſte,
Than Heaven has made her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In your caſe ſpecially; for out of doubt,
Heaven never made a more Accompliſh'd Creature.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What means the Man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I come juſt now from Entertaining her:
Whoſe Wit, and Beauty ſo excell all thoſe
Of her fair Sex, whom I have ever known,
That my Deſcription of her would appear
Rather Detraction, than a Juſt Report
Of her Perfections.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Certainly he mocks me; he never could
Have choſen a worſe Sufferer of Scorn;
But I will yet contain my ſelf awhile
To ſee how far he'l drive it; Say you, Sir,
That you have Seen, and Entertain'd my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, Don Henrique, and with ſuch full Contentment,
So rais'd above Expreſſion, that I think
The Pains, and Cares of all my former Life
Rewarded with Exceſs, in the Delight
Of thoſe few Minutes of her Converſation;
'Tis true, that Satisfaction was abridg'd
By her well-weigh'd Severity; to give me
A greater Pleaſure in the Contemplation
Of her diſcreet Obſervance of the Rules
Of Decency; not ſuffering me, though now
Her Husband, any longer to enjoy
So great a Happineſs, you being abſent.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: I am confounded;Aſide. but I muſt diſſemble
My Aſtoniſhment, till I can unfold
The Myſterie; She might have ſpar'd that Caution,
But I ſuppoſe you'l eaſily Forgive
An Error on the Better ſide.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, I have ſeen ſo much of her Perfections
In that ſhort Viſit, I ſhall ſooner doubt
All Definitions in Morality,
Than once ſuppoſe her capable of Error.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: This Expoſition makes it more Obſcure:Aſide.
I muſt get him away. Sir, is't not time
I bring you to your Chamber? it is late,
And I believe that you have need of Reſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I ſhould accept your offer, were I not
Oblig'd, as late as 'tis, to ſee a Friend
Before I go to Bed.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: I'l wait on you, Sir, if you I give me leave.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I humbly thank you, Sir, but can't conſent
To give you ſo much trouble; I'l return
Within an hour at fartheſt.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: When e'r you pleaſe; y'are wholly Maſter here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I never ſaw a man ſo Diſcompos'd,Aſide.
What e'r the matter is.
Ernesto, I muſt make a ſtep to ſee
A Friend near hand; bid Sancho follow me;
And ſtay you in my Chamber till I come.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Your Servant, Henrique waits on him to the door. Sir; this ſudden Salley hence
At this time of the night, and newly arriv'd
From a long Journey, does imbroil me more.
But now I will not long be in Suſpenſe;
I'l to my Siſter's Chamber.

div.stage: Enter Carlos as Henrique is going into Porcia's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ho Don Henrique, there is haſte requir'd; all's
Prepar'd, and if the Quarrie lodg'd ſhall prove
Worthy of our own Swords, we may employ them;
If not, the Sword of Juſtice ſhall revenge
Our Injuries; for the Corrigidor
Is ready with a Band of Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Speak ſoftly; Don Antonio is arriv'd,
And ſome of his may over-hear us.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: That's very unlucky, but does he know
That Porcia's miſſing?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: I think not yet.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Come, let's away; we have no time to loſe.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Pray ſtay awhile; I labour with a Doubt
Will burſt me if not clear'd before I go.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: What Cozin! will you looſe an Opportunity
Never to be recover'd? are you mad?
Will you permit the Villains to eſcape,He pulls
And laugh at us for ever? come away.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Well, I muſt go; and let time make it out;

q.l: The worſt Eſtate of Human Life is Doubt.

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: The SCENE is DON OCTAVIO's Houſe.
Enter Octavio angrily puſhing Diego, and Porcia following.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: VIllain, thou haſt undone us, curſed Villain;
Where was thy Soul, had Fear quite Baniſh'd it?
And left thee not one grain of common Senſe?

sp.speaker: Porc.
sp.l: Was there ever ſo fatal an Accident?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Why, Traitor, did'ſt thou not let me know it,
As ſoon as we were come into the Houſe?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: What would y' have done if ye had known it then?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I would have fally'd out, and Kill'd the Rogue,
In whoſe Power thou haſt put it to Deſtroy us;
Can it be doubted, but that long ere this
He has acquainted Henrique where we are?
From whoſe black Hage we muſt immediately
Expect to encounter all the pernicious
Effects of Malice, back'd by Seeming Iuſtice;
Curſe on all Cowards! better far be ſerv'd
By Fools, and Knaves: they make leſs dang'rous Faults.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Am I in fault, becauſe I'm not a Cat?
How could I tell i'th' dark whether that Raſcal
Was a Knight Errant, or a Recreant Knight?
I thought him one of us, and true to Love;
Were it not for ſuch Accidents as theſe
That mock Man's Fore-caſt, ſure the Deſtinies
Had ne'r been plac'd amongſt the Deities.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Peace, cowardly Slave; having thus plaid the Rogue,
Art thou Sententious grown? did I not Fear
To Stain my Sword with ſuch Baſe Blood, I'd let
Thy Soul out with it at a thouſand wounds.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: VVhy then a thouſand Thanks to my Baſe Blood
For ſaving my Good Fleſh.Aſide.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Pardon, my deareſt Miſtris, this Exceſs
Of Paſſion in your preſence.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What ſhall we do Octavio? we are loſt
For ever; if we ſhould ſtay here, my Brother
Will be upon us inſtantly. Alas!
My own Life I value not Octavio,
Where yours, my Better life, ſuch hazard runs;
But O my Honor! O my Innocence!
Expos'd to Scandal; there's my deepeſt Senſe.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Though the Complexion of your Brother's Malice.
Reſemble Hell, it is not Black enough
To caſt a Stain upon your Virgin Whiteneſs.
As Contraries compar'd ſet off each other,
The siſter's Brightneſs will expoſe the Brother.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: O my Octavio! he is ſtill my Brother;
But what do you reſolve to do?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I muſt reſolve and ſuddenly, but what
I ſwear know not, there have been ſuch Turns
In my Misfortunes, they have made me giddy.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You muſt determine, time waſtes Octavio.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If I ſhould lead you through the Streets, and meet
Th'in quiſitive Juſtice, I daring not
T'avow my ſelf upon the other ſcore
You know of, you might that way be in danger;
We muſt not venture 't; To Diego. Run Raſcal, and fetch
A Chair immediately.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: A pretty Errand at this time o'th' night;
Theſe Chair-men are exceedingly well natur'd,
Th'are likely to obey a Servant's Orders
After ten a clock.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Ye Powers above, why do ye lay ſo great
A Weight on Human Nature, and beſtow
Such an Unequal Force to bear our Loads?
After a long purſute through all thoſe Storms,
Which Hell-bred Malice, or the Power of Fate
Could ever raiſe, t'oppoſe a Noble Love;
To be at length poſſe s'd of the Rich Mine,
Where Nature ſeem'd to have lodg'd all her Treaſure;
And in an inſtant have it raviſh'd from me,
Is too rude a Trial for my tir'd Patience
To ſu •• ain; I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: My Senſe of this Misfortune Equals yours,
But yet I muſt conjure you to ſubmit
To Heavens Decrees; ſuch Reſignation
'Tis poſſible, their Juſtice may induce
The miſchief to divert, though ne'r ſo near.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Ah Porcia to part with you!

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Looſe not your ſelf with me, though we are forc'd
To Separate, yet we are not Divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Whilſt our Souls act by Organs of the Senſe,
'Twixt Death and Parting there's no difference.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Conſult your Reaſon, then you will comply;
Making a Virtue of Neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Ah lovely Maid, 'twas not allow'd to Jove
To hold at once his Reaſon, and his Love.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: The Chair is come, Sir, juſt as I expected.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Even where it was; they are deeply engag'd
At New Cut, and will not leave their Game,
They ſwear, for all the Dons in Sevil.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: A curſe upon theſe Rogues! I'l make 'em come,
Or put ſome of 'em in a condition
To be carri'd themſelves.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Madam, though I was never yet Unkind
To my own Perſon, I am ſo much troubled
At the Diſquiet my Miſtake has brought you,
That could I do it conveniently, i'faith,
I could even cudgel my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Away Buffon, is this a time for fooling?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is my noble Friend Octavio?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Did you not meet him at the door, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: He went out juſt as you came in.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, Addreſſes himſelf to Porcia. I might have gone to Bed, but not
To Reſt, without returning to enquire
Anew of Yours, and of my Friends Condition;
And once more offer you my Service.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I take the boldneſs in Octavio's abſence
To return his with my moſt humble Thanks
For your late generous Aſſiſtance of us,
And for this new Addition to our Debt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, though I have not the Happineſs
To be Known to you, yet my conſtant Friendſhip
With Octavio is of an antient Date;
And all Occaſions where I may expreſs
The Fervour of it, are moſt welcome to me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O Madam—I'm out of breath with running.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: What Accident, Flora, brings you hither?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: A ſad one, Madam, and requiring haſte,
To give you timely notice on't; Don Carlos,
Aſſiſted by the light o'th' Riſing Moon,
And by a Miſtake of ſome of your Train,
Has Trac'd you to this Houſe, and in my hearing,
Inform'd your Brother of the Place, and Manner
Of your Retreat, who is now coming hither
Accompani'd with the Corigidor,
To ſeize on whomſoever ſhall be found
Within theſe Walls, upon pretence of Murder.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: O cruel Accident!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Madam, make haſte, get out at the back door;
Or you will certainly be met withall.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: How vile a Creature am I now become!
For though in my own Innocence ſecure,
As to my ſelf, t'others I ſhall appear
Some wicked Woman, that has ſold her Honor
To purchaſe Infamy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They'l inſtantly be here.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: O that Octavio ſhould juſt now be abſent!
But to expect till he return were madneſs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Y' have reaſon, Madam, and if you dare truſt
Your Perſon to the Conduct of a Stranger,
Upon my Honor, Lady, I'l Secure you,
Or Periſh in th'Attempt.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Generous Sir, how ſhall a wretched Maid,
Abandon'd by her Fare to the purſute
Of an Inhumane Brother, e'rbe able
Either to Merit, or Requite your Favours?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, they're more than Paid in the Admiſſion,
And your Acceptance of them will transfer
The Obligation, making me the Debtor.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: To your Protection I reſign my ſelf,
With equal Gratitude and Confidence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come Madam, there is no time to be loſt;
Diego, find out your Maſter preſently,
And tell him, that the Danger not allowing
Our Stay till his Return, I ſhall convey
His Miſtris ſafely to a Nunnerie.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: And Flora, ſtay you here to bring me word,
What he reſolves to do in this our deſp'rate Condition.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Madam, I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But ſtay;Going out returns. I ſwear I'd like to have committed
A foul Miſtake; the Monaſtery Gates
Will not be open'd at this time of Night,
Without a ſtrict Inquiry into the Cauſe;
Beſides, 'tis poſſible, that once Lodg'd there,
She may be out of my Friends Power, or mine,
Ever to get her thence if it be known.
Lady, I have thought better on't; I ſhall
Conduct you to my Brother-in-law's houſe;
A Perſon of ſuch Quality, and Honor,
As is fit to engage in your Protection;
And there my Wife may have the Happineſs
T' accompany you, and pay the Offices
Due to your Virtue, and diſtreſs'd Condition:
And going to a Houſe that's ſo much mine,
Make account, Madam, 'tis to your own Home.
Sancho, ſtay you here to attend Octavio,
And guide him the next way to my Apartment;Turning to Sancho.
Here is the Key; I ſhall have little uſe on't,
Having left Ernesto waiting for me there.
One word more, Sancho; let Octavio know
'Tis my advice that he come in a Chair;
He by that means may ſcape Examination,
Should he be met with.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Flora, I pray do you continue here,
And if by any accident Octavio
Should hindred be from coming after us,
Obſerve his Motions, and where he Fixes;
Then return home; and I ſhall find ſome way
Of ſending to you to inform my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I ſhall not fail t'obſerve your Orders, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, I'm ready to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: An cruel Brother! ah my dear Octavio!
O how perverſe, and rigorous is my Fate!
Thus to torment me betwixt Love and Hate.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: 'Tis no ſmall Compliment my Maſter makes
Your Ladie, and her Gallant, at this time
O'th' night to quit his Brother-in-laws, and leave
So fair a Bride as Porcia all alone.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What? is his Miſtris's name Porcia too?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Yes; and if ſhe has but as fair a Hand-maid
As your ſelf, I ſhall ſoon forget my Damſel
In the Low-countries.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If your Low-country Damſels reſemble us,
You would not be put to't to forget firſt;
But I believe that you are ſafe enough;
I have not heard ſuch Praiſes of their Wit,
But that we may ſuppoſe they have good Memories.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Is not my Maſter yet return'd?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Well; now have we an Honorable Cauſe
To wear the Beadles Livery; faith, Flora,
If your tender Sex had not been privileg'd
From this harſh Diſcipline, how prettily
Would the Beadles Crimſon Lace ſhow upon
Thy white back.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'T won't do ſo well as on a darker ground;
'Twill ſuit much better with your Tawney hide.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: I pray, Camerade, is it the Mode in Sevil
To be Whip'd for Company?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Oh! a well-bred Soldier will ne'r refuſe
Such a Civility to an old Friend;
This is a new way of being a Second,
To ſhew your Paſſive Courage.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: We Soldiers do not uſe to ſhow our Backs.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Not to your Enemies; but, Sir, the Beadle
Will prove your Friend, for your Blood being Heated
With your long Journey, Breathing of a Vein
Is very requiſite.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Would to Heaven that I were in the Camp again:
There we are never ſtript till we are dead.

div.stage: Enter Octavio, and the Chair-men appear at the door.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Be ſure you ſtir not thence till I return.To the Chair-men.
Sirrha, where's Porcia?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: She's fled away i'th'dark, with a Young man Of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Raſcal, leave your fooling.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: There's none i'th' caſe, Sir, 'tis the wiſeſt thing
She ever did, had ſhe ſtaid your return,
She would have fall'n into thoſe very Clutches,
In which you will immediately be grip'd,
Unleſs you make more haſte: Flora is come
With all poſſible ſpeed, to let you know
Th'are coming with the Juſtice to lay hold
Of all within this Houſe, upon pretence
Of a moſt horrid Murder; be quick, Sir;
And ſave your ſelf. She's ſafe in a Nunnerie;
Conducted thither by Antonio;
Where, poor Lady, ſhe's dropping for you now
More Beads, perhaps, than Tears.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Peace Screetch-Owl; Fire conſume that Tongue of thine.
What ſaiſt thou Villain? in a Nunnerie?
Porcia in a Nunnerie? O Heavens! nothing
But this was wanting to make me Deſperate;
What hope's there left ever to get her thence,
After ſuch Accidents as theſe made Publique?
Ah Flora, is it true that my dear Porcia
Is gone into a Monaſtery?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Once, Sir, 'twas ſo reſolv'd, and Diego ſent
To give you notice on't; but afterwards
He being gone, they chang'd their Reſolutions:
There's one can tell you more—

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: My Maſter bad me ſtay to let you know
He has convey'd her to his own Apartment,Pointing to Sancho.
In his Brother-in-laws Houſe, a perſon
So eminent in Quality, and Credit,
That the ingaging him in her, and your
Protection, Sir, may much avail you both;
Beſides, ſhe'l have the pleaſure there of being
Very well treated by my Maſter's Bride.
There he'l expect you, Sir, and does adviſe
Your coming in a Chair, to avoid Queſtion
In caſe of any Encounter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: And my walking by, Sir, as an Attendant,
Will paſs you without ſcruple for a Lady.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I'l take his counſel, he's a generous Friend,
Come Chair-men, away. To Sancho. Pray, friend, do you guide us.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Up with your Burden Beaſts, and fall forth-with
To your Half-Trot.

div.stage: The Chair is carri'd over the Stage, Diego, Sancho, and Flora follow.
div.l: A Noiſe within, Follow, follow, follow.
div.stage: Enter Carlos, the Corigidor, and Serjeants, purſuing Sancho, Flora, and Diego.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: This is one of Don Cupid's pretty Jeaſts.
W'are ſtruck upon a Shelf before we could
Put out to Sea.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Oh, we are undone Diego!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You find,To the Corrigidor. Sir, my Conjectures not ill grounded.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What are you, Sirrha?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: A Living Creature, very like a Man,
Onely I want a Heart.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Y'are pleaſant, Sir, pray Heaven your mirth continue.
Who is that Woman with the Veil?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Let her anſwer for her ſelf, ſh'has a Tongue,
Set it but once a going, and ſhe'l tell
All that ſhe knows, and more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Make her diſcover her face.

div.stage: [One of the Serjeants goes to lift up her Veil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hold Friend; Cozin, if it ſhould be Porcia,
'Twere not fit to expoſe her here.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis very well conſider'd, go you to her,
And ſpeak to her in private.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis I Sir, Flora, who being commanded
By my Lady—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Speak ſoftly prithee Flora, 'tis enough;
I underſtand the reſt, and pitty her;
Bid her ſit ſtill i'th' Chair, I'l do my beſt
To ſave her from the Fury of her Brother.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He thinks 'tis Porcia there, a good Miſtake,
It may ſecure Octavio for the preſent
From the hands of this rude Rabble;To Octavio in the Chair. Sit ſtill,
They take you for my Miſtris Sir, I'l follow
The Chair, and have a watchful Eye on all
Occaſions, that may further your Eſcape.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We have found our wandring Nymph.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Is it Porcia her ſelf?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, 'tis her Woman Flora following
The Chair, wherein they were conveying her
To ſome other place.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: We arriv'd luckily, had we but ſtaid
A moment longer, they had all been fled.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Will you have us ſee, Sir, who's in the Chair?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Forbear Fellow! To Carlos. Her own Folly's puniſhment
Enough't'a Woman of her Quality,
Without our adding that of Publique ſhame.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: 'Twas luckily thought on, when you oblig'd
Don Henrique to expect us at your Houſe;
For had he come, and found his Siſter thus,
'T had not been poſſible to have reſtrain'd
His Paſſion from ſome great Extravagance.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I could not think it fit to let him come;
For one of ſuch a Spirit could ne'r brook
The ſight of thoſe had done him theſe Affronts,
Without invading thoſe ſtrict Rules, which might
Render his Life obnoxious to the Laws.
'Tis better that a buſineſs of this nature,
(Chiefly 'twixt Perſons of ſuch Quality)
Should rather be reduc'd by Mediation
(If it be poſſible) to ſome fair Agreement,
Than to a publique Trial by the Law,
Or, which is worſe, ſome Barbarous Revenge.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: This Fellow (if I am not much miſtaken)
Is Don Octavio's Man.Looking upon Diego.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Who do you belong too, Friend?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: To no body, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Do not you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Yes Sir, but my Maſter is not himſelf.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Take his Sword from him Serjeant.The Serjeant goes to take away his Sword.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Diego diſarm'd by any other hand
Than by his own? know Friend, it is a Weapon
Of ſuch dire Execution, that I dare not
Deliver it, but to the hands of Juſtice.

div.stage: The Corrigidor receives the Sword, and gives it to one of his Serjeants.

sp.l: Signior, pray call for it, when you come home,
And hang't up in your Hall, then under-write,
This is bold Diego's Sword; O may it be
Ever from Ruſt, as 'tis from Slaughter free.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou art a Fellow of a pleaſant humour.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Signior, I never pain my ſelf for Love,
Or Fame, or Riches, nor do I pretend
To that great ſubtilty of Senſe to Feel
Before I am Hurt, and for the moſt part
I keep my ſelf out of Harms way.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: The Definition of a Philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Come, leave your fooling Sirrha, wher's your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I am afraid we are not to be parted.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Whom do you mean?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: My Maſter, my Self, and the Fool your Worſhip
Mentions, for ſure one that had any Wit,
Would never ſerve a Lover Militant;
He had better wait upon a Mountebank,
And be run through the Body twice a week
To recommend his Balſom.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This Fellow's an Original.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: But of ſo ill a hand, I am not worth
The hanging up, Sir, in my Maſters room,
Amongſt the worſt of your Collection.

div.stage: Enter Serjeants with two Foot-men, and two Maid-ſervants.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.l: An't pleaſe your Worſhip, we have ſearch'd the Houſe,
From th' Cellars to the Garrits, and theſe are all
The living Cattel we can find.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Friends take a ſpecial care of that ſame Varlet,
And the Waiting-woman; we'l find a way
To make them tell the Truth, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O Diego! muſt we be Priſoners together?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Why, that's not ſo bad as the Bands of Wedlock,
Flora.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Come, let's away; but whither to convey her—
To her own Houſe certainly were not fit,
Becauſe of her incenſed Brother.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: If you approve it, Cozin, I'l carry her
To mine; for ſince we ſeek (if poſſible)
The buſineſs to compoſe, ſhe will be there
With much more Decency, and Satisfaction,
And leſs expos'd to Cenſure of the World,
Being in a Kinſmans Houſe, and having there
My Siſter to accompany her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This buſineſs cannot be in better hands,
Than yours; and there I'l leave it, and bid you
Good-night.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Your Servant Cozin,As the Corrigidor goes out. I wiſh you well home.
Cozin, you may be pleaſe to take your Serjeants
Along with you; there are without two Servants
Belonging to Don Henrique, they'l ſuffice
To guard our Priſoners, and with far leſs notice.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Come Serjeants, follow me.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Well,To the Footmen and Maids. you may go about your buſineſs, Friends,
I'l not be troubled with ye; I am glad
We did not find Octavio here; though I
Might unaffected Ignorance pretend,
I would not bring him (though by chance) t'his End.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Well, I am now ſufficiently inſtructed,
And ſince there is no notice taken of me,
I'l fairly ſteal away, and give my Maſter
Account of this Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Take up the Chair, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: A Lovely Dame they bear, 'tis true, ſhe's ſomething
Hairie, but that's a ſign of Strength.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Make haſte, I long to let Don Henrique know,
That his loſt Siſter is by my dexterity
Recovered, and I hope to find ſome means
To calm his Furie, and to repoſſeſs
My Cozin Porcia, and (if't be poſſible)
Octavio of his good Graces. Come away.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: How like an Aſs he'l look, when op'ning the Shell,
His Worſhip finds within ſo rough a Kernel.

div.stage: The Scene Changes to Don Antonio's Apartment in Don Henrique's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, baniſh all your Fears, you are now
Safe in this Houſe; be pleas'd to remain here,
Till I ſhall bring ſome Lights, and acquaint Porcia
With th' Honor ſhe receives in entertaining
So fair a Gueſt.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Who is't you ſay you will advertiſe Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Wife Porcia; have but a little patience;
And ſhe ſhall wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Is her name Porcia too? I pray Heaven ſend her
A better Fate than her diſtreſſed Names-ſake.
O Octavio! O Love! how dear do you
Coſt me! where am I brought? what Houſe is this?
What with my Fears, and Darkneſs, I have loſt
All my meaſures; I can't ſo much as gueſs
What Quarter of the Town it is w'are in,
For to avoid th' Encounter of my Brother,
And his Revengeful Train, we have been forc'd
To make ſo many Turnings, I am Giddy.
But thanks to Providence I have this comfort,
That I am in a place out of his reach.

div.stage: Enter Antonio with two Lights, and ſets them on the Table.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, my Wife will preſently attend you.
Pardon I pray my abſence for a moment.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Now I begin to hope my Sighes, and Tears,
Have in ſome ſort with the juſt Heavens prevail'd
At length to free me—Looking about her. But what do I ſee!
Am I awake, or is it an Illuſion?
Is not this my Brother's Houſe? Is not this
The Quarter joining to my own Apartment?
There is no room for Doubt, and my Misfortunes
Are always Certain; Miſerable Creature,
That I ſhould be thus Bandi'd up and down
From one Hazard t'another, greater ſtill.
Ah cruel Heavens! what have I ever done
To deſerve this laſting Perſecution?
But how came I here? brought by Octavio's friend,
Upon whoſe Virtue I did ſo relie
That I my Brothers Malice durſt defie.
Can he betray me? ſure I am in a Dream.
But if Octavio— O vile Suſpition!
Octavio falſe? no, Truth and He are one.
'Tis poſſible his Friend may guilty be;
But to what end ſo baſe a Treacherie:
And if Perfidious, how could he be his Friend.
I am confounded with the various forms
Of my Misfortunes, Heightned ſtill the more,
The leſs I can their Hidden Cauſe explore.
This onely's evident, that I muſt flie
Immediately this fatal place; But why
Struggle I thus with Fate? ſince Go, or Stay,
Death ſeems alike to wait me every way.She weeps.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I wonder much what Lady this can be
Antonio mentions.Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pardon, my deareſt Miſtris, the Liberty
Which I ſo early take; but I preſume
Such is your Generous Tenderneſs to thoſe,
Whoſe ſad Misfortunes, not their Faults, have driven
Into Diſtreſs, that you will think your ſelf
Oblig'd to him, who gives you the occaſion
To exerciſe thoſe Virtues which do Viſit
Others, but Reſide with you; This fair Lady—
But ſhe will beſt relate her own ſad Story;
Whilſt I ſeek out Don Henrique, and engage him
Both to Protect and Serve her with his Credit.

div.stage: Upon Camilla's approach Porcia takes the Handkerchief from her Eyes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ha!She runs after Antonio. what's that I ſee? ſtay, ſtay Antonio.
It is not fit Don Henrique,— but he's gone,
And we are loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Porc.
sp.l: O Heavens! is this Antonio, the ſame Man
To whom I am Betroth'd? then my Deſtruction
Is inevitable.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Are you an Apparition? or are you
Porcia her ſelf? ſpeak, that when y' have ſaid it thrice
I may not yet believe you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You well may Doubt even what you See Camilla;
Since my Diſaſters are ſo new, and ſtrange,
They ſever Truth from Credibility.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How is it poſſible you ſhould be here?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I know not how, onely of this I'm ſure,
I have not long t'expect the diſmal end
Of my ſad Tragedy; ſince 'tis evident
The Perſon that hath led me to this Place,
This fatal Place, is the abus'd Antonio;
Who with my Cruel Brother has conſpir'd
To take away my wretched life, and choſe
This Scene as fitteſt for their Cruelty.
And thus, ſtrange Fate! (through ignorance betraid)
I have Protection ſought from the ſame Partie,
Whom I have Injur'd, and have made my Husband
Th'onely Confident of his own Affront:
Who to accompliſh his too juſt Revenge,
As well upon my Family, as Perſon,
Gives me up to be Murder'd by my Brother.
So whilſt I'm branded as a Faithleſs Bride,
He'l be deteſted as a Particide.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Prodigious Accident! but wert thou blind
Not to know thine own Houſe unhappy Porcia?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Alas, how could I in ſo dark a Night,
In ſuch Confuſion, and ſo full of Fear?
Beſides, he brought me in by the Back way,
Through his own Quarter, where was neither Light,
Nor any Creature of the Family.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Although I cannot comprehend the ſteps
Of this your ſtrange Adventure, yet dear Cozin,
Your caſe (as I conceive) is not ſo deſperate.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: We eaſily perſwade our ſelves to hope The things we wiſh; but Cozin, my condition
Will not admit Self-flattery, and what
Can you propoſe to temper my Deſpair?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Don't you remember, how this very Evening
Antonio's Man finding me in your Quarter
Without a Veil (you having put on mine)
That he appli'd himſelf to me, and I
By your command, your Perſon did aſſume?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Yes very well.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The Maſter ſince has by the Man's Miſtake
Been happily led into the ſame Error,
And I not diſabus'd him yet, in hopes
It might produce Advantage to us both.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Oh! he has ſpoken with my Brother ſince;
Who ſure has Undeceiv'd him long ere this.
No, without doubt they having found themſelves
Affronted both, have both conſpir'd my death.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: How Cozin can that be? if Don Antonio
In your Protection has engag'd himſelf,
And is Octavio's Friend.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Cozin, if you impartially reflect
On the Affront which I have done Antonio,
You will not wonder much if he recede
From the ſcarce-troden Path of rigid Honor
To meet with his Revenge; and to that end
Proceeds thus cautelouſly, and does ſeign
Not to know me, that he may diſavow
Both to Octavio, and to all the world,
Th'Infamy of Betraying a poor Maid
To loſs of Life and Honor.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Misfortunes make you rave; this vile Suſpition
Is inconſiſtent with Antonio's Fame:
You may as well believe that Nature will
Reverſe the order of the whole Creation,
As that Antonio, a Man, whoſe Soul
Is of ſo ſtrong, and perfect a Complexion,
Should ere deſcend to ſuch a ſlaviſh Sin.
And if we had the leiſure, I could give you
Such reaſons to convince you of your Error,
That you would eaſily acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I had forgot her near Concernments for
Antonio. Aſide. Pardon and Pitty me Camilla;
My mind is by Afflictions made ſo Weak,
I'm ready to believe Impoſſibilities.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I Pitty thee with all my heart; but Cozin,
If Antonio not knowing you, nor your
Relations, ſhould chance to find your Brother,
And him inform of what has paſs'd, and that
He has convey'd the diſtreſſ'd Partie hither,
He'l preſently imagine it is you;
And then (I fear) 'twill be impoſſible
(Though he ſhould interpoſe with all his power)
To ſtop the Torrent, or divert his Rage
From breaking in, and executing on us
That horrid Parricide, which (though too late)
It may be he himſelf would execrate.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: There's too much ground for what you fear Camilla:
But if we could ſecure our ſelves this night,
There were ſome hopes that we tomorrow may
Engage both Don Antonio, and your Brother
To find out ſome Expedient to redeem me
From this deplorable condition.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Were you onely in pain for your Security
This night, I know an eaſie Remedy
For that.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Which way my Deareſt?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Why what does hinder us from making uſe
(On this occaſion) of the ſecret Door,
By which (you know) you have ſo often paſt
Into our Houſe (upon more pleaſing Errands?)
By this we ſhall theſe Benefits obtain;
Of Safety from your Brothers preſent Fury,
And time to try if Carlos, and Antonio
May be ingag'd to mediate in this Buſineſs.
And I have cauſe to think you will not find
Antonio ſo implacable, as you
Imagine.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I conceive you Cozin; Fool that I was,
To think a Heart once Conquer'd by your Eyes
Should e'r become another Virgin's Prize.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So late; a Gueſt in's Houſe; that's come ſo far;
On ſuch a Buſineſs; and not yet come home?Aſide.
There's ſomething in't I cannot comprehend.
I cannot, Madam, yet find out your Brother,
But ſure 'twill not be long ere he return.
Then i'l acquaint him with the Accident
Has made his Houſe this Ladie's Sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Here is a glympſe of comfort, for I ſee
He takes my Cozin for Don Henrique's Siſter;
O bleſs'd Miſtake ſo luckily continu'd!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am by his permiſſion Miſtris here,
And ſince that I am pleas'd Sir, 'tis enough,
Without our troubling him with the Account
Of her ſad Story.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, as to th'Excuſe, but 'twere fit
He knew it too, that we might ſerve our ſelves
Of his Credit in this Ladie's Protection.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Though I did promiſe the Corrigidor
Not to ſtir from his Houſe, till his return,
Yet I could not obtain it of my ſelf;
I'm ſo impatient to unfold the Riddle
Of Don Antonio's ſeeing of my Siſter,
And entertaining her in her own Lodging;
I ſhall not now be long i'th' dark.He ſees her. O Heavens!
'Tis ſhe her ſelf, and Camilla with her:
Were all my Servants mad, or all agreed
T'abuſe me, in affirming ſhe was fled?
But Don Carlos, was he mad too, to ſwear
That he had trac'd her to an other Houſe?
Certainly I, or they muſt be Poſſeſs'd;
Or ſome Inchantment reigns within theſe Walls.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O here comes Don Henrique, I'l now acquaint him
With your ſad Story Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I fear we are undone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Don Henrique—

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I'm dead if he proceed, but how to hinder him—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here's a Lady with your Siſter Porcia—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, I ſee who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Since you know her Sir, you will the eas'lier
Excuſe my boldneſs.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Boldneſs, in what Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To have been th' occaſion of your finding her
Here, with your Siſter, at this time of night.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Lord Sir, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Truly there was a Neceſſity in it,
Which will, I hope, excuſe my Interceſſion
With you in her behalf.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Now all comes out.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: I underſtand you Sir, ſhe does deſire
To paſs this night with Porcia, to aſſiſt her
In ordering her Nuptial Ceremonies:
Let her ſtay here a God's name.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: If he does not diſſemble, my Condition
Is not ſo deſperate as I imagin'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I hope you'l pardon this great Liberty;
So early a Confidence will need it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: 'Tis more than enough Sir, that you deſire it,
Th'Occaſion too does juſtifie her ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true Sir, the Occaſion did inforce me
Thus boldly to preſume upon your Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Ha' done for Heavens ſake, is it a Novelty
Think you for Porcia, and her Cozin-Germin
To paſs a Night together?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo near a Kinſwoman of his?
Strange Inadvertence in her not to tell me
Her relation to him, when I nam'd him firſt.
I'd made fine work on't had I told him all.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: She knows I owe her many a Good-turn
Upon Octavio's ſcore,Looking on the Ladies. and hope ere long
To be able to repay her to the full.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Can he declare his mind in plainer terms?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I cannot tell which of us two he means,
But I begin to fear that he knows all.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Since 'tis ſo late, pray give the Ladies leave
To retire to their Chambers; Go in Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Brothers Words, and his Behaviour
Imply ſome Myſtery; I muſt be ſilent
Till I diſcover more.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let us begone, w'are loſt if we ſtay here;
I'm confident he counterfeits this Calm
To diſguiſe his Revenge, until Antonio,
And the reſt of the Houſe are gone to Bed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But we ſhall ne'r be able to get out
Whilſt they continue in the outward Rooms.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Yes, by the Garden-dore, but I'm afraid 'Tis ſhut.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No; now I think on't, Flora went that way,
And left it open.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Come, lett's be gone; I hope Heaven does ordain
Eaſe by that Door which firſt let in my Pain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'l onely make a ſtep Sir, to my Lodging,
And then return to you immediately.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I humbly thank you Sir, I know the way,
And ſhall not ſtay above a Moment from you.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Y'are Maſter here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'l now go ſee whether my Servant Sancho
Has brought Octavio to my Apartment,
As I directed him.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Heavens! was there ever ſo ſtrange a Myſtery!
Don Carlos he affirm'd that thoſe we fought with
Had convey'd Porcia away, and when I come
To ſeek her in the Houſe I find her miſſing,
To ſecond this, her Waiting woman Flora
Tells me that ſhe went down, about that time,
Into th' Garden; Antonio, not long after,
Affirms that he both ſaw, and entertain'd her
In her own Apartment, where I now find her,
And Camilla with her: What can this be?
Theſe ſure are Riddles to poſe an Oedipus;
But if by my own Senſe I am aſſur'd
My Honor's ſafe, which was ſo much in doubt,
What matter is it how 'tis brought about.

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT.
div.stage: Enter Diego, Flora, and Geraldo accompanying the Chair, greaping as i' the dark.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: DAme Flora, and Signior Diego, go in there.
And you my Friends, ſet down the Chair i' th'door;
And when the Party's enter'd, pull it to;
'Twill lock of 't ſelf; that done, you may be gone:
There's Mony for you; I'l go fetch a Candle.

div.stage: [Exit Geraldo. Diego, and Flora go in, and the Chair being ſet in the door, Octavio goes out into the room, the Chair-men clap to the door, and go away.
Enter Octavio, Diego, Flora, at another door.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What!Groaping as i' th' dark put in all alone here i' the dark!
And the door ſhut upon me! Diego, Flora.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Here am I Sir, and Flora too, unleſs
My Senſe of feeling fails me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I can't conjecture where we are; I durſt not
So much as peep out of the Chair, ſince Flora
Gave me the warning; but where e'r I am,
'Tis better far than in the Serjeants hands.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Though now i'th' dark, I know well where we are:
I have too often walk'd the Streets, Octavio,
From your Houſe hither, upon Cupid's Errants,
Not to know the back door of Carlos's
Apartment; 'tis there I am ſure w' are now.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Curſe on thee, Flora! had'ſt thou loſt thy wits
Not to let me know it ſooner! think'ſt thou
I ſhould have tamely ſuffer'd them to bring me,
Like a poor Bird ſhut in a Cage, t' a place,
Where I muſt look for nothing but Deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: A Gypſie told me by my Palm long ſince,
A ſour-fac'd Damſel ſhould be my deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Suſpend a while your Apprehenſions, Sir;
You may eſcape before the Candles come;
The door was wont to open on this ſide;
If not, I have another way in ſtore.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Flora, Striving to open the door. I cannot make the Lock go back.

div.stage: Ger. unlocks it on the other ſide, and coming in with a Candle, meets with Octavio, and starting back and ſtumbling lets the Candle fall, then running out again locks faſt the door.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Nay then, i'faith, w'are faſt; I heard him give
The Key a double Turn.
Here's a fair Trial for your Maiden breath,
Flora blow 't in again, let's owe your Mouth
More Light, than yet your Eyes could e'r impart.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Light's caſt away on ſuch an Owl as you;
But yet I'l trie.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Thanks, gentle Flora, to your Virgin Puff;
'Tis a Strong breath that can o're-come a Snuff. [Aſide
But I had rather 't had been let alone:
If I muſt needs be ſlain, unleſs it were
Behind my back, I'd have it i' the dark;
For I hate to be kill'd in my own preſence.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What muſt we do Flora? all my hope's in you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: There is yet room for Hope; there's Back-ſtairs
Beyond that inner Chamber, that goes down
Into the Garden, if the door be open,
As certainly it is, the way is eaſie.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Come, let's loſe no time; prethee guide us Flora.

div.stage: The Scene changes to Don Henrique's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: As well pleas'd as I am, to find my Honor
Leſs Deſperate than I thought, I cannot reſt
Till I have drawn from Porcia a Confeſſion
Of the whole Truth, before ſhe goes to bed;
She's in her Chamber now, unleſs by new
Enchantments carried thence.

div.stage: As he is going towards Porcia's Chamber, Enter Carlos in haste.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: I can't imagine what ſhould make Don Henrique
Quit the Corrigidors till we return'd:
One of his Servants tells me he's come home.
O here he is; now ſhall I raiſe a ſtorm
Which (if we do not take a ſpecial care)
Will ſcarce b' allaid without a ſhowr of Blood;
Yet I muſt venture't, ſince it ſo imports
Our Friendſhip, and the Honor of our Houſe.
Happineſs is a ſtranger to Mankind,
And like to a Forc'd Motion, it is ever
Strongeſt at the beginning, then Languiſhing
With time, grows weary of our company;
But to Misfortunes we ſo ſubject are,
That like to Natural motion they prove ſtill
More Vigorous in their Progreſs.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What means this Philoſophical Preamble?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: You I'know too ſoon I fear.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Don Carlos, I am now ſo well recover'd
From all m'Inquietudes, that for the future
I dare defie the Malice of my Stars
To cauſe a new Relapſe into Diſtemper.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Cozin, I'm ſo ſurpriz'd with this great change,
That my Confuſion does ſuppreſs my Joy;
But ſince y'are ſo much Maſter of your Paſſions,
I'l ſpare my Ethicks, and proceed to give you
In ſhort the Narrative of our ſucceſs;
The Corrigidor (as we did expect
Forward to ſerve you in th'Affair I mention'd)
Was pleas'd to go along with me in perſon,
With a ſtrong Band of Serjeants, to the place,
Where I attended by your Servants led him:
Cozin, 'twas there; it wounds my heart to ſpeak it;
And I conjure you ſummon all your Patience:
'Twas there I found—

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Whom Cozin did you find? for ſince I'm ſure
You found not Parcia there; my Concernments
In your Diſcoveries are very unlikely
To diſcompoſe me.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: I would to Heaven we had not found her there.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What's that you ſay, Cozin, my Siſter there!

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Yes Sir, your Siſter.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: My Siſter! that's good i'faith: ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Why do you laugh? is the Diſhonor of
Your Family become a Laughing Matter?
This is a worſe Extreme me-thinks than t'other.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: How can I chooſe but Laugh to ſee you Dream;
Awake for Heavens ſake; and recall your Senſes;
Porcia there ſaid you?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Yes Sir, Porcia I ſay; your Siſter Porcia;
And which is more, 'twas in Octavio's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Why ſure y'are not in earneſt, Cozin.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: As ſure as you're alive I ſound her there.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Then you tranſport me, Sir, beyond all patience:
Why Cozin, if ſhe has been ſtill at home,
Antonio ſeen, and entertain'd her here,
Accompani'd by Camilla; if even now
I left them there within; Is't poſſible
You ſhould have found her in Octavio's Houſe?
To be here, and there too, at the ſame time,
None ſure but Janus with his double face
Can e'r unfold this Myſtery.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Sir, let me adviſe you; Abuſe not your ſelf:
I tell you poſitively I found her there:
And by the ſame Token, her Waiting-woman
Flora was there attending her.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Flora! dear Cozin, do not ſtill perſiſt
Thus to affirm impoſſibilities.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Sure you are making ſome Experiment
Upon my Temper, and would fain provoke
My Patience to ſome ſuch high Diſorder,
That I ſhould ne'r hereafter have the face
When you are in you Fits to play the Stoick.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Cozin, I ſwear to you upon my Honor,
'Tis not above a quarter of an hour,
Since I did ſpeak with Porcia, and your Siſter
In that very Apartment, and am now
Returning to them in my Siſter's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: And Sir, I ſwear to you upon my Honor,
'Tis not above a quarter of an hour,
Since I left Porcia carried in a Chair
From Don Octavio's Houſe, your man Geraldo
Conducting the Chair-men to mine, and follow'd
By Flora, whilſt I came to find you out
T' acquaint you, Sir, with this unpleaſing news:
But fit for you to know as ſoon might be.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: This Queſtion, Cozin, may be ſoon decided,
Pray come along, her Chamber's not far off.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: And my Houſe is but the next door, let's in.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: You'l quickly find your Error.
Here comes your Servant, whom I left to Guard her;
He'l inſtantly convince you of the Truth.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O Sir!

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What brings you hither Geraldo?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: O Sir, I bring you ſuch rare news, your Enemy,
Your Enemy Octavio— I'm out of breath.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What does the Varlet mean?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Sir, I ſuppoſe Don Carlos has inform'd you
That he left me to ſee your Siſter P'rcia,
With Flora, and Diego Octavio's Man
Safely convey'd t'his Houſe.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: See now Don Henrique, who was i' the Right.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I did as he commanded me, and put them
All three into Don Carlos's Anti-chamber;
Porcia in the ſame Chair which brought her thither;
And for more ſafety made the door be lock'd;
Whilſt I went down in haſte to fetch a Light.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: As ſure as Death this Madneſs is Infectious;
My Man is now in one of Carlos Fits.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Returning with a Light a moment after,
No ſooner open'd I the door, but Heavens!
Who ſhould I ſee there ſtanding juſt before me
In the ſame place where I left Porcia, but
Octavio, your Enemy Octavio.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Here is ſome Witch-craft ſure; what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Amaz'd at th' ſight, I let the Candle fall;
And clapt the door to; then I double-lock'd it,
And brought away the Key.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: But how could he get in, if you be ſure
You lock'd the door, when you went out for Lights?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I know not whether he was there before,
Or got in after, but of this I'm ſure,
That there I have him now, and ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: I am ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Let's not, Don Carlos, now perplex our ſelves
With needleſs Circumſtances, when? and how?
Thoſe Queries are too Flegmatick for me;
If the Beaſt be i' th'd Toil it is enough;
Let us go ſeize upon him; he muſt die.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good Brother, what unhappy Man is he,
Whom you ſo poſitively doom to death?
I have a Sword to ſerve you in all occaſions
Worthy of you, and me.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: His intervening, Carlos, is unlucky,
How ſhall we govern our ſelves towards him
In this Affair? ſo unfit for his knowledge?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Antonio is a Man of ſhining Honor;
But having ſuch a ſhare in this Affront,
If once he know't, I am afraid he'l bring
Fuel, not Water to Don Henrique's Fire.

Don Henrique,
To Henrique you muſt ſuddenly reſolve
What anſwer to return, he's not a Man
To be put off with any ſlight Pretences;
Nor yet to be engag'd in ſuch an Action,
As bears th'appearance rather of Cruelty,
Than Honor, and you know, Antonio needs
No freſh Occaſions to ſupport his Name;

l.q: Who Dangers ſeek, are indigent of Fame.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I find my coming hath diſorder'd them,
There's ſomthing they would fain conceal from me;
All here is diſcompos'd, what er's the matter.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Perhaps 'twere better to ſuſpend a while
The Execution of your juſt Revenge:
Time, and mature weighing of Circumſtances,
Never did harm in Actions of this Nature;
Where one has ſtill the Party in his Power.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: A Curſe on your Tame Propoſition Carlos!

q.l: He, who the Rules of Temperance neglects,
From a Good Cauſe may produce Vile Effects.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: To Antonio. I doubt not of your kind Concurrence, Sir,
In all the near Concernments of a Perſon
Alli'd to you as I am; but Noble Brother,
It were againſt the Laws of Hoſpitality,
And Civil Prudence to engage a Gueſt
(Newly arriv'd after ſo long a Journey)
In an occaſion, Sir, of Blood, and Hazard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If ſuch be the occaſion, I muſt then
Acquaint you freely, that I wear a Sword,
Which muſt not be excluded from your Service;
I'm ſure you are too Noble t'imploy yours
But I confeſs there are Affronts ſo great,
And heightned by ſuch odious Circumſtances,
As do releaſe us from the uſual Forms
Of Generous Revenge; and ſet us free
To tak't on any Advantage.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Though with Regret I ſee, Sir, I muſt yield
To your exceſs of Generoſity;
This onely I ſhall ſay to ſatisfie
Your juſt Reflections; that my Reſentments
Are grounded on Affronts of ſuch a Nature,
That as nothing but the Offender's Life
Can e'r repair them, ſo as to the Forms
Of taking that Revenge, they can't admit
Of the leaſt ſcruple.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Honor's my Standard; and 'tis true, that I
Had rather Fall, than Bluſh for Victory;
But you are ſuch a Judge of Honor's Laws▪
That 'twere Injurious to ſuſpect your Cauſe.
Allow me, Sir, th'honor to lead the way.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: If Porcia be there too, (as I believe)
'Twill prove, I fear, a fatal Tragedy;
But ſhould ſhe not be there; yet 'tis too much
For ſuch a Heart as mine, through Ignorance
To have betraid a Gentleman, though Faulty,
In to ſuch Cruel hands; I muſt go with them;
But ſo reſolv'd, as in this Bloody ſtrife
I'l ſalve my Honor, or I'l loſe my Life.

div.stage: The Scene changes to Carlos's Houſe.
Enter Octavio, Diego, Flora with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O the unluckineſs! I vow t'you Sir,
I have ſcarce known that door e'r lock'd before.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: There's no Remedy Flora, I am now
At the Mercy of my Enemies.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Having broken into another's Ground,
'Tis juſt i'faith▪ you ſhould be put i' th' Pound.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: The Tide of my ill Fate is ſwoln ſo high,
'Twill not admit encreaſe of Miſerie;
Since amongſt all the Curſes there is none
So wounds the Spirit as Privation.
For 'tis not where we Lie, but whence we Fell,
The Loſs of Heaven's the greateſt Pain in Hell;
When I had ſail'd the doubtful Courſe of Love,
Had ſafely gain'd my Port, and far above
My Hopes, the precious Treaſure had ſecur'd,
For which ſo many Storms I had endur'd;
To be ſo ſoon from this great Bleſſing torn,
That's hard to ſay, if 'twere firſt Dead, or • orn,
May doubtleſs ſeem ſuch a tranſcendent Curſe,
That even the Fates themſelves could do no worſe;
Yet this I bore with an erected face,
Since Fortune, not my Fault caus'd my Diſgrace;
But now my Eyes unto the Earth are bent,
Conſcious of meriting this Puniſhment,
For truſting a fond Maid's Officious Care,
My Life, and Honor's taken in this Snare;
And thus I periſh on this unſeen Shelf,
Purſu'd by Fate, and Falſe unto my ſelf.
Flora, He pulls out his Tablets. when I am dead, be ſure that you
Theſe Tablets give to Porcia; there ſhe'l find,
That to th'Extremeſt Moment of my Life
I conſtantly purſu'd thoſe Noble Ways,
Which might Deſerve her, though I could not Have her.
Give me the Candle.

div.stage: Octavio ſets the Candle on a Table, and ſits down as to write in his Tablets.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: A double Curſe upon all Love in earneſt,
All Conſtant Love; 'tis ſtill accompani'd
With ſtrange Diſaſters; or elſe ends in that
Which is the worſt of all Diſaſters Marriage.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Sure you could wiſh that every body living
Had ſuch a Soul of Quick-ſilver, as yours,
That can fix no where.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Why 'twould not be the worſe for you, dear Flora,
You then might hope in time to have your Turn,
As well as thoſe, who have much better Faces.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You, I preſume Sir, would be one o'th'lateſt
Which I ſhould hear of, yet 'tis poſſible
That one might ſee you, before you ſhould be welcom.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: She has Wit, and good Humor; excellent
Ingredients to paſs away the time;
And I have kindneſs for her Perſon too,
But that will end with Marriage, and poſſibly
Her good Humor; for I have ſeldom known
The Husband, and the Wife make any Muſick,
Though when aſunder they can play their parts;
Well, friend Diego, I adviſe you to Look
Before you Leap, for if you ſhould be Coupled
To a Yoak inſtead of a Yoak-fellow,
'Tis likely you may wear it to your Grave.
Yet, honeſt Diego, now I think on't better,
Your Dancing, and your Vaulting days are done,
Faith all your Pleaſures are three Stories high,
Th'are come up to your Mouth, for you are now
For Eaſe, and Eating, th'onely Joys of Life,
And there's no Cook, nor Drie-Nurſe like a Wife.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I could find Reaſons too for Matrimony,
A Stale Maid is a horrible reproach,
I muſt confeſs it; and a Waiting-woman
Does onely change a Miſtris for a Maſter;
I may quit her, 'tis true, but not my Husband,
And on the other ſide ſhe may quit me,
And turn me off, when old, and good for nothing.
A Husband's bound to keep me ſtill; In fine,
For ought I can perceive the Scales are Equal,
I may throw Croſs and Pile, which Life I'd have,
The Single Begger, or the Marri'd Slave;
But heark! the Door within, from whence we came
Is newly open'd, or my Ears deceive me.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Methoughts I heard it too, let us peep in.
sp.stage: [They look into the next Room, and start back.
sp.l: O Sir, Runs to Octavio. w'are loſt, I ſee two Female-Giants
Coming moſt terribly upon us.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Away you troubleſome Fool.

div.stage: Enter Camilla and Porcia, the one with a Key, the other with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I'm confident no body ſaw us paſs
From th'other Houſe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: However, let's go through my Brother's Quarter,
And open the Back-door into the Street;
'Tis good in all Events t'have a Retreat
More ways, than one.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: O Heavens!A door claps behind, and both look back. our ſureſt is cut-off, the Wind
Has clapt that door to thorough which we came.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The Accident's unlucky, 'tis a Spring-lock,
That opens onely on the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let's on the faſter, and make ſure of th'other. Octavio here!

div.stage: Octavio hearing them ſtarts up with the Tablets in's hand.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Porcia in this place! may I truſt my Senſes,
Or does my Fancy create theſe Chimeras?

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Either we Sleep, and Dream extravagantly;
Or elſe the Fairies govern in this Houſe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ah! deareſt Miſtris, you ſhall never make me
Quit you ſo again.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: But can that be Octavio?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I was Octavio; but I am at preſent
So much aſtoniſh'd, I am not my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What can the meaning of this Viſion be?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: My deareſt Porcia, how is't poſſible
To find you in this place, noble Antonio
Having ſo generouſly undertaken
Your protection?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Did he not yours ſo too? and yet I find
Octavio here, where he is more expos'd
Than I, to ſure deſtruction; I am loath
To ſay 'tis he, who has Betraid us both.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Antonio falſe? it is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: It is too evident.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Peace Slave; he is my Friend, of Noble Blood,
Whoſe Fame's above the Level of thoſe Tongues,
That Bark by Cuſtom at the brighteſt Virtues,
As Dogs do at the Moon.

sp.speaker: Por.

l.q: How hard it is for Virtue to ſuſpect.

sp.l: Ah Octavio! we have been both deceiv'd;
This vile Antonio is the very Man,
To whom my Brother without my Conſent,
Or Knowledge has Contracted me in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Antonio the Man to whom y'are Contracted,
Porcia the Bride whom he is come to Marry?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Why did you not acquaint me with it ſooner?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Alas, I have not ſeen you ſince I knew it;
But thoſe Few hours ſuch Wonders have produc'd,
As ſurpaſs all Belief, and do require
More time, than your unſafe Condition here
Will allow us to make you underſtand it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Dear Friends, I cannot blame your Apprehenſions,
Nor your Suſpition of Antonio's Friendſhip:
But I am ſo poſſeſs'd with the Opinion
Of his great Virtue, that I ſhall as ſoon
Believe Impoſſibilities, as his
Apoſtacie from Honour.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What's her Concernment in Antonio, Porcia?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: O, that's the ſtrangeſt part of our ſad Story;
And which requires moſt time to tell you.

div.stage: A Blaze of Light appears at the Window, and a noiſe within.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: See, Flora, at the Window, what's that Light,
And Noiſe we hear.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: O Madam! we are all undone, I ſee
Henrique, Carlos, and their Servants with Torches
All coming hither, and which is wonderful,
Antonio leading them with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Thou dream'ſt, diſtracted Wench; Antonio falſe?
It is impoſſible.
sp.stage: Camilla runs to the Window, and turning back ſays,
sp.l: All ſhe has ſaid is in appearance true,
There's ſure ſome hidden Myſtery which thus
Abuſes us; for I ſhall ne'r believe
Antonio can tranſgreſs the Rules of Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Friendſhip's an Empty Name, made to Deceive
Thoſe, whoſe Good Nature tempts them to believe;
There's no ſuch thing on Earth, the beſt that we
Can hope for here is faint Neutrality.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Ye Powers above! what pleaſure can ye take
To Perſecute Submitting Innocence?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Retire, dear Porcia, to that inner Room,
For ſhould thy cruel Brother find thee here,
He's ſo revolted from Humanity,
He'l mingle thine, with my Impurer Blood.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That were a kind of Contract; let him come;
We'l meet at once Marriage, and Martyrdom.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Soul of my Life retire.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I will not leave you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Thou preſerv'ſt me by ſaving of thy ſelf;
For they can murder onely half of me,
Whilſt that my better part ſurvives in thee.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: I will die too, Octavio, to maintain,
That different Cauſes form the ſame Effects;
'Tis Courage in you Men, Love in our Sex.

div.stage: [Octavio takes hold of her to lead her away.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Help me Camilla.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You muſt be rul'd, your Preſence will increaſe
Your Brother's Fury, and Octavio's Danger.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: That Argument is Irreſiſtible.

div.stage: They retire to the other Room, and Octavio waits on them to the door.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Nay if you are at that,Taking Flora by the hand the Devil take
The hindmoſt; 'tis for your ſake, deareſt Flora,
I ſhun theſe Honorable Occaſions.
Having no Weapon,As he goes out with Flora, turning to Octavio. Sir, 'tis fit that I
March off with th' Baggage.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I'm now upon the Frontiers of this Life,
There's but one ſtep to Immortality;
And though my cruel fortune has allow'd me
No other Witneſs of my Tragick end,
But my Inhumane Murtherers; yet my Death
Shall not Diſgrace either my Life, or Love;
To th'other World this Honor I will bear,
That as I ſtill have Liv'd, and Lov'd, ſo I
Encounter Death with the ſame Conſtancy.

div.stage: Enter Antonio, Henrique, Carlos, and Geraldo, with their Swords drawn, Antonio before the reſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is the Man whoſe Inſolence, and Folly
Has thus miſled him to Affront my Friend?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here is the Man thou ſeek'ſt, and he, whom thou
So baſely haſt Betraid.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! what is't I ſee? It is Octavio My Friend.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Not thy Friend, Antonia; but 'tis Octavio,
Who by thy Perfidie has been betraid▪
To this forlorn Condition; but vile Man,
Thou now ſhalt pay thy Treachery with thy Life.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hold Octavio; though thy Injurious Error
May tranſport thee, it ſhall not me beyond
The Bounds of Honor; Heaven knows I thought
Of nothing leſs, than what I find, Octavio
In this place.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What pauſe is this, Antonio? all your Fervour
In the Concernments of your Friend, reduc'd
To a tame Parly with our Enimy?
Do all the Promiſes, you have made to me,
T'aſſiſt my juſt Revenge, conclude in this?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Do all the Promiſes you have made to me,
T'aſſiſt my Virtuous Love, conclude in this?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Where is your wonted Bravery? where your Kindneſs
To ſuch a near Allie?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Where is your former Honor? where your Firmneſs
To ſuch an antient Friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What courſe ſhall my Diſtracted Honor ſteer
Betwixt theſe equal,Aſide. oppoſite Engagements?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What, demur ſtill? nay then I'l right my ſelf.

div.stage: Henrique makes at Octavio, Antonio turns on Octavio 's ſide.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wh'attaques Octavio muſt paſs through me.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: I muſt lay hold on this Occaſion.Aſide.
Good Cozin, I conjure you to reſtrain
Your Paſſion for a while, there does lie hid
Some Myſtery in this, which once unfolded,
May poſſibly produce the Means of making
That Reconcilable, which now ſeems Deſp'rate.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Sweetly propos'd, Sir, an Accommodation?
Think'ſt thou my Anger's like a Fire of Straw,
Onely to Blaze, and then expire in Smoak?
Think'ſt thou I can forget my Name, and Nation,
And Barter for Revenge, when Honor Bleeds?
His Life muſt pay this Inſolence, or mine.

div.stage: [He makes at Octavio again, Antonio interpoſes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Mine muſt protect his, or elſe periſh with him.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Since neither Faith, nor Friendſhip can prevail,
'Tis time to trie what proof you are, Antonio,
Againſt your own near Int • rſt; Know, that Man,
Whom you protect againſt my juſt Revenge,
Has ſeconded his Inſolence to me
By foul Attempts upon my Siſter's Honor;
Your Porcia's Sir, if this will not enflame you.

div.stage: [Porcia endeavours to come out, Camilla holds her.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: This Injury's beyond all Sufferance.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: To what exceſs of Folly does our Rage
Tranſport us Men!Aſide. this moſt Important Secret,
Which Tortures could not have made him diſcover,
He (onely to advance his blind Revenge)
Has now unforc'd declared to that Perſon,
From whom, of all men living, he ought moſt
To have conceal'd it.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: How! I attempt your Siſter's Honor Henrique?
The Parent of your black Deſigns, the Devil,
Did ne'r invent a more malicious Falſhood;
'Tis true, that I have ſerv'd the Virtuous Porcia,
With ſuch Devotion, and ſuch Spotleſs Love,
That, though Unworthy, yet ſhe has been pleas'd
To recompence my Paſſion with Eſteem:
By which, ſhe has ſo chain'd me to her Service,
That here I vow either to Live her Prize,
Or if I Die, to fall Loves Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O Heavens! what's that I hear? thou bleſſed Angel
Guardian of Honor, I do now implore
Thy powerful aſſiſtance to preſerve
That Reputation, which I hitherto
By Virtuous Actions have maintain'd unblemiſh'd;
In vain, Don Henrique, you deſign to change
My Reſolutions; it muſt ne'r be ſaid,
That Paſſion made Antonio recede
From the ſtrict Rules of Honor; Sir, I tell you,
Nothing can make me violate my firſt
Engagement.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Nay, then thou ſhalt Die too, Perfidious Man;
Ho! Geraldo, Pedro, Leonido.

div.stage: Enter Geraldo, Pedro, Leonido, with their Swords drawn, and joyn with Henrique, Carlos interpoſes.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: For Heaven's ſake, Cozin, draw not on your ſelf
The horrid Infamy of Aſſaſinating
Perſons of Noble Blood by Servile Hands.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Do you Defend them too? Kill 'em I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Retire Octavio, I'l ſuſtain their ſhock.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Octavio retire?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Truſt me you muſt, they will ſurround us elſe;
Through that narrow Paſſage they'l Aſſail us
With leſs advantage.

div.stage: They retire fighting off the Stage: Henrique and his Men perſuing them, and Carlos endeavouring to ſtop Don Henrique.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What d'ye give back, ye Men of mighty Fame?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Don Henrique, you ſhall quickly find 'tis Honor,
Not Fear makes me retire.

div.stage: Enter preſently Antonio and Octavio at another door, which Antonio bolts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now we ſhall have a breathing while at leaſt
Octavio, and time to look about us;
Pray ſee yon other door be faſt.

div.stage: Octavio steps to the door where they went out, and Henrique bounces at the door they came in at.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Geraldo, Within. fetch an Iron Bar to force The door.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Heaven has heard our Prayers; th'are both ſafe here.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Let's go to 'em Camilla.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis better to ſtay here a while, and hearken
What Reſolution of themſelves they take.

div.stage: [Antonio goes to both the doors to ſee if they be faſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So, 'tis now as I could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: What do you mean, Generous Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To Kill thee now my Self, having perform'd
What Pre-engagement did exact from me
In your Defence gainſt Others; my Love now
Requires its Dues, as Honor has had his;
There's no Protection for you from my Sword,
But in your Own, or in your frank renouncing
All Claim to Porcia; She is ſo much mine,
That none muſt Breath, and have the Vanity
Of a Pretender to her whilſt I Live.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: My Claims to Porcia I ſhall ne'r renounce,
But ſtill aſſert them by all noble ways;
Yet, Sir, this hand ſhall never uſe a Sword
(Without the laſt Compulſion) 'gainſt that Man,
Who has ſo much Oblig'd me; no Antonio,
You are ſecurely Guarded by the Favours,
You have conferr'd upon me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, let not your pretended Gratitude
Enervate your Defence; 'tis not my cuſtom
To ſerve my Friends with Proſpects of Return;
I therefore, Sir, do freely here acquit you
From all the Obligations, you are pleas'd
To own from me.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: You may, Sir, if you pleaſe, forbear to add
New Favours to my' account; but you can never
Subſtract thoſe, which are paſt; and till that Debt
Be fully paid, I ſhall not dare t' appear
I'th' Liſts againſt ſo Generous a Creditor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your Scruples are ill grounded; 'twas Octavio
(My antient Friend) whom I deſign'd to Serve;
Not that Diſloyal Man, who has invaded
My Honor, and my Love; 'Tis the Intent Creates the Obligation, not th' Event.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I call thoſe Powers, who both Diſcern, and Puniſh,
To witneſs for me, that I never knew.
You e'r pretended to Don Henrique's Siſter,
Before I came within theſe fatal Walls:
This I declare, onely to clear my ſelf
From th'Imputation of Diſloyalty;
And to prevent the Progreſs of your Error.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How can I think you ſhould ſpeak Truth to me,
Who am a Witneſs y'have been Falſe to her,
To whom, you now profeſs ſo high Devotion.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: I falſe to Porcia! take heed, Antonio,
So foul an Injury provokes too much;
But, Sir, I muſt confeſs I owe you more,
Than the Forgivneſs of one groſs Miſtake.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Rare Impudence! I muſt not truſt my Senſes.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: If we cannot adjuſt this Competition,
Let us our Fortunes, not our Paſſions charge
With this our breach of Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Leave your Diſcourſes, and Defend your ſelf;
Either immediately Renounce all Claims
To Porcia; Shaking his Sword. or this muſt ſpeak the reſt.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Nay,They fight. then, this muſt Reply.

div.stage: They without bounce at the door, as if they were breaking it open.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Why do I doubt? there is no means to ſave him
From the preſent danger, but by another,
Perhaps as great, but ſomething more remote;
I'l do't.

div.stage: Whilſt they fight, Porcia breaks from Camilla, and unbolis the door, then runs back into her place.
Enter Henrique, Carlos, Leonido, Geraldo, with their Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: What's this! Antonio fighting with Octavio!
This Bravery is exceſſive, Gallant Friend;
Not to allow a ſhare in your Revenge
T' him, who's moſt concern'd; he muſt not die
Without ſome Marks of mine.

div.stage: Henrique makes at Octavio, and Antonio turns to Octavio's ſide.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay, then my Honor you invade anew,
And by Aſſaulting him, Revive in me
My Pre-engagements of Protecting him
Againſt all others.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Why were not you Antonio fighting with him?
Were you not doing all you could to Kill him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Henrique, 'tis true; but finding in my breaſt
An equal ſtrife 'twixt Honor, and Revenge;
I do in juſt compliance with themboth
Preſerve him from your Rage, to Fall by mine.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Brave Man, how Nicely he does Honor weigh!
Juſtice her ſelf holds not the Scales more Even.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: My Honor ſuffers more as yet than yours,
And I muſt have my ſhare in the Revenge;
Either he muſt renounce all Claims to Porcia,
Or Die immediately.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It is agreed: that he muſt Doe, or Die:
But by no other hand, than mine.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Ceaſe your Contention, and turn all your Swords
Againſt this Breaſt; whilſt Porcia' and I have breath,
She muſt be mine, there's no Divorce but Death.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: I'l hear no more, protect him if thou canſt

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.l: Kill the Slave, kill him, I ſay.

div.stage: Henrique makes at him, and Carlos endeavours to enterpoſe.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: For Heaven's ſake hold a Moment; certainly
There's ſome Miſtake lies hidden here, which clear'd,
Might hinder theſe Extremes.

div.stage: Henrique and his Servants preſs Antonio and Octavio.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Theſe Errors muſt be clear'd, before they grow
Too fatal, but I fear your Brother's fury
Will not admit of Reaſon.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I'm ſure I'l try, though it ſhould coſt my life.

div.stage: Enter Porcia and Camilla from the Inner Room.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Don Henrique.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Antonio, Carlos

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Octavio.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Ha! how came ſhe here?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Did not I tell you that ſhe was brought hither
By my Directions? you would not believe me.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: But how then could Octavio come hither?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Nay, that Heaven knows; you heard as well as I
Your Man's Relation.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Ah thou vile Woman! that I could deſtroy
Thy Memory with thy Life.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hold,He offers to run at Porcia, Antonio interpoſes. Sir, that muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: What may not I do Juſtice upon her Neither?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No Sir; although I have not yet the Honor
To know who ſhe x's, I have this night engag'd
My ſelf, both to Secure, and Serve her.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: He knows not Porcia; who was i' the right
Don Henrique, You, or I?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: He not know Porcia? whom not an hour ſince
I ſaw, and ſpoke with, entertaining her
In his Apartment; ſure we are Enchanted,
And all we ſee's Illuſion.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Allow me, Henrique, to diſpell theſe Charms;
Who is't, Octavio, you pretend to? ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: You might have ſpar'd that Queſtion; ſince none
Knows ſo well as you, 'Tis Porcia I adore.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Porcia's my Wife;Offers to make at Octavio. Diſloyal Man thou Di'ſt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Hold Sir; which is the Porcia you claim too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Can you be'n doubt of that? you know too well
The Conqueſt, that you made ſo long ago
Of my ſurprized heart in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Conqueſt! Surpris'd! Flanders! what can this mean?

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: New Riddles every moment do ariſe,
And Myſteries are born of Myſteries.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Thanks be to Heaven, our work draws near an end;
Cozin, it belongs to you to finiſh it.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: To free you from that Labyrinth, Antonio,
In which a ſlight Miſtake, not Rectifi'd,
Has involv'd us all; know, th'ſuppos'd Porcia,
Whom you ſo long have lov'd, 's the true Camilla.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And you, Don Henrique, know, Octavio
Has always been your Siſter's faithful Lover;
And onely Feign'd a Gallantry to me,
His real Paſſion to Diſguiſe from you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Octavio and Antonio run to one another and embrace. Generous Octavio.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Brave Antonio, how happy are we both!
Both in our Loves, and Friendſhips!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Man's Joys do ne'r to their Perfection riſe,
Till when by Croſſes heightned, they ſurprize.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Camilla takes Antonio by the hand and leads him to Carl. Don Carlos. This, my dear Brother, is that brave Commander,
To whom you owe your Life, and Liberty;
And I much more, the ſafety of my Honor.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Is this the Gallant Leader, who reſcu'd us
With ſo much Valour from th'Enemy's hands?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: If you knew him ſo well, why did not you
Acquaint me with it ſooner? 'twas a fault Camilla.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas,Drawing Carlos aſide. my deareſt Brother, Gratitude
Conſpiring with the Graces of his Perſon,
So ſoon poſſeſs'd him of my Heart, that I
Deſpairing e'r again to ſee him; and
Aſham'd of ſuch a Viſionary Love,
Durſt never truſt my Tongue with my own Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: 'Tis enough.
Take here from me the Hand of her,Don Carlos preſents Camilla to Antonio. whoſe Heart
Heaven, and your Merits have long ſince made yours
Without my Knowledge; may her Virtue pay
Some part of that, which we both owe to yours.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here with your leave, Antonio takes Porcia's hand, and kiſſes it with great reſpect. and hers I ſeal the Vows
Of my Eternal Faith unto you both.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: But let's take heed, Antonio, leſt whilſt we
Are Joying in our mutual Happineſs,
Don Henrique's ſcarcely yet compos'd Diſtemper
Revive not, and Diſorder us afreſh:
I like not his Grim Poſture; you know well
After a Tempeſt, though the Wind be laid,
There often does remain for a good while
A dangerous Agitation of the Waves;
He muſt not yet be truſted with himſelf.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis well thought on, let us go to him.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Here with Reſpect we wait the Confirmation
Of Heaven's Decrees from your Indulgence, Octavio holding Porcia by the hand advances towards Henrique. Sir.
This Lady▪ your Incomparable Siſter,
Can witneſs that I never did invade
Your Paſſion for Camilla; and Pedro's death
Happen'd by your miſtaken Jealouſie;
The Cauſes of your Hate being now remov'd,
'Tis juſt, Don Henrique, the Effects ſhould ceaſe.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: I ſhall conſult my Honor.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: You cannot take a better Counſellor
In this Caſe, than you Own, and Siſter's Honor;
What, to ſecure them both, could have been wiſh'd
Beyond what Fate hath of it ſelf produc'd?

sp.speaker: Henr.

l.q: How hard it is to Act upon Conſtraint.

sp.l: That, which I could have Wiſh'd, I now would Flie;
Since 'tis obtruded by Neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Noble Don Henrique, make account of me
To be as truly yours by this Alliance,
As if a Brother's Name ſubſiſted ſtill.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: I muſt conſent,Aſide. I ſee, or worſe will follow.

q.l: He is a Fool who thinks by Force, or Skill
To turn the Current of a Woman's Will

sp.l: Since fair Camilla is Antonio's Lot,
I Porcia yield to Don Antonios Friend.
Our Strength, and Wiſdom muſt ſubmit to Fate.
Script of my Love, I will put off my Hate.
Here, Henrique takes Porcia by the hand and gives her to Octavio. take her hand; and may ſhe make you, Sir,
Happier, than ſhe has done me.

div.stage: Enter Diego and Flora from the inner Room.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Had ſuch Diſorders e'r ſuch a Come-off?
Me-thinks 'twould make a Rare Plot for a Play.They all embrace, but Henrique coldly.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Faith Flora, I ſhould have the worſt of that;
For by the Law of Comedy 'twould be
My Lot to Marry you.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Well thought on, Diego, though ſpoken in Jeſt;
We cannot do, I think, a better thing
In Earneſt, than to make them Two Joyn Hands.
What ſay'ſt thou to it, Flora?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Indeed I have had ſo many Frights this night,
That I am e'n afraid to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l:
Give me thy Hand Flora,
Diego takes her by the hand. it is a Bargain;
I promiſe thee, dear Spouſe, I'l do my beſt
To make thee firſt Repent this Earneſt Jeaſt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: That time ſhall trie.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: Since this laſt happy Scene is in my Houſe,
You'l make Collation with me are we part.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Sir, you had beſt make haſte, elſe what you call
Collation, may prove a Breakfaſt, for 'tis
Near twelve a Clock.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thus end the Rare Adventures of Five Hours;
As ſometimes Boiſterous Storm's in Gentle Shours.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE.
div.stage: Diego comes ſtealing in, and is follow'd by Henrique, who ſtays at the Door, and Liſtens.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen!
Let the Dons, and Monſieurs ſay what they will;
〈◊〉 our parts, we are for Old England still.
〈◊〉 e's a fine Play indeed, to lay the Scene
〈◊〉 th • ee Houſes of the ſame Town, O mean!
〈◊〉 we have ſeveral Plays, where I 〈◊〉 fie.
〈◊〉 Devil to tell where the Scene does lie:
• imes in Greece, and then they make a step
••• nſilvania thence at one Leap
To Greece again: this ſhows a ranging Brain,
Which ſcorns to be confin'd t' a Town in Spain.

lg.head: Then for the Plot;
lg.l: The poſſible Adventures of Five Hours;
A copious Deſign, why' in ſome of ours
Many of th' Adventures are impoſſible,
Or if to be atchiev'd, no Man can tell
Within what time; this ſhows a rare Invention,
When the Deſign's above your Comprehenſion:
Whil'ſt here y'are treated with a Romance Tale,
And a Plot cover'd with a Spaniſh Veil.

lg.head: As for the Style;
lg.l: It is as eaſie as a Proclamation,
As if the Play were Pen'd for th'whole Nation.
None of thoſe thundring Lines, which uſe to crack
Our Breaths, and ſet your Wits upon the Rack.
Who can admire this Piece, or think it good;
There's not one Line, but may be underſtood.

lg.head: The Raillerie;
lg.l: As innocent, as if't had paſt the Teſt
Of a full Synod: not one Baudy Jeaſt;
Nor any of thoſe Words of Double Senſe,
Which makes th' Ladies, to ſhow their Innocence;
Look ſo demure; whil'st by a ſimp'ring Smile,
The Gallant ſhows he underſtands the Style.
But here you have a Piece ſo ſubtly Writ,
Men muſt have Wit themſelves to find the Wit:
Faith that's too much; therefore by my conſent,
We'l Damn the Play.

sp.speaker: Henr.
sp.l: Think'ſt thou,Pointing to the Pit. Impertinent,
That theſe, who know the Pangs of bringing forth
A Living Scene, ſhould e'r deſtroy this Birth.
You ne'r can want ſuch Writers, who aſpire
To pleaſe the Judges of that Upper • ire.
The Knowing are his Peers, and for the reſt
Of the Illiterate Croud (though finely dreſt)
The Author hopes, he never gave them cauſe
To think, he'd waſte his Time for their Applauſe.
You then (moſt equal Judges) freely give
Your Votes, whether this Play ſhould Die, or Live.

lg.head: THE EPILOGUE AT COURT
lg.l: W'Have paſs'd the Lords, and Commons; and 〈◊〉
At length, Dread Sir, to hear Your Final Doo •
'Tis true, Your Vaſſals 〈◊〉 may Vo • e the Laws,
Their 〈…〉 Divine Applauſe.
This Shining Circle then will all ſit Mute,
Till one pronounce from you▪ Le Roy le Ven • .
